'''Ethics''' is the branch of [[axiology]] – one of the four major branches of [[philosophy]], alongside [[metaphysics]], [[epistemology]], and [[logic]] – which attempts to understand the nature of [[morality]]; to define that which is [[right]] from that which is [[wrong]]. The [[Western philosophy|Western tradition]] of ethics is sometimes called '''moral philosophy'''.
    −
==History==
      −
The earliest known written evidence for a formal study of ethics can be traced to early Greek civilization, with substantial further development made by Roman and other thinkers of the Classical period. Important Greek ethicists include the [[Sophists]] along with [[Socrates]], [[Plato]] and [[Aristotle]], who developed [[ethical naturalism]] and forms the foundation of what is now referred to as [[virtue ethics]]. The study of ethics was developed further by [[Epicurus]] and the [[Epicureanism|epicurean]] movement, and by the [[stoicism|stoics]] starting with [[Zeno of Citium]]. However the stoics did not delve into the topic with the same rational rigor as Aristotle in his Nicomachean ethics, the product of his own lectures and discourses with his teacher Plato, and other Athenian intellectuals.
  −   −
In Europe, the formal study of philosophy stagnated until the medieval era of [[Maimonides]], [[Thomas Aquinas]] and others. At this time the debate between [[natural law]] and [[divine law]] as a source of moral authority was of great importance.
  −   −
Modern Western philosophy began in the 17th & 18th centuries with the work of [[Thomas Hobbes]], [[David Hume]] and [[Immanuel Kant]] (who gave rise to the [[categorical imperative]]). Kantian ethics is the commonly cited example of [[deontology|deontological ethics]], one of the major divisions in ethics. In contrast to this and virtue ethics (mentioned above), [[consequentialism]] was developed by people such as the [[utilitarianism|utilitarians]] [[Jeremy Bentham]], [[William Godwin]] and [[John Stuart Mill]].
  −   −
[[Arthur Schopenhauer]] (1788-1860) followed Kant and is notable as the first major European philosopher to be influenced by Eastern ethical thought, in particular the ethical achievements of [[Upanishadic]] writings of ancient [[India]]. [[Friedrich Nietzsche]] was influenced by both Kant and Schopenhauer but developed ethics into a new direction becoming a powerful critic of the 19th century moral climate, arguing that concepts such as true and false (and good and evil) are merely interpretations of reality. This developed later into [[existentialism|existentialist]] and [[postmodernism|postmodernist]] lines of ethical reasoning.
  −   −
The study of analytic ethics went on the 20th century with [[G. E. Moore]] and [[W. D. Ross]], followed by the emotivists, [[C. L. Stevenson]] and [[A. J. Ayer]]. Some modern philosophers who have done serious philosophical writing on ethics include [[John Rawls]], [[Elliot N. Dorff]], [[Jürgen Habermas]], [[Christine Korsgaard]], [[Charles Hartshorne]] and [[Ayn Rand]].
